Lupus Anticoagulant Test: Meaning, Symptoms, Treatment

Dr. Mansi
September 20, 2024

Table of Contents

In the complex world of autoimmune disorders, lupus anticoagulant (LA) stands out as a unique and often misunderstood entity. Despite its name, which suggests a protective role against clotting, lupus anticoagulant is actually associated with an increased risk of blood clots and various complications.

In this blog, We will discuss the goal of the lupus anticoagulant test, symptoms, and therapy, offering insightful information to medical professionals and patients alike. One of the three main antiphospholipid antibodies linked to a higher risk of thrombosis and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS), an autoimmune condition marked by excessive blood clot formation, organ failures, and pregnancy difficulties, is the lupus anticoagulant.

What is Lupus Anticoagulant?

Before we go into the technicalities of the lupus anticoagulant test, let’s define what lupus anticoagulant is. This phrase may appear confusing, but it refers to a specific type of antibody that can disrupt the normal blood clotting process.

One kind of antibody is lupus anticoagulant, which is a member of the antiphospholipid antibody group. Our immune system normally produces antibodies to defend us against bacteria and viruses, but in LA, these auto-antibodies can raise the risk of thrombosis, and blood clots in arteries and veins.

The antiphospholipid syndrome may be brought on by these antibodies (APS). An autoimmune condition called APS increases the risk of blood clot formation significantly. Phospholipids, an essential part of cell membranes, are attacked by LAs. These antibodies can raise the risk of thrombosis because phospholipids are essential for blood coagulation. Antiphospholipids might result in blood vessel constriction, stroke, blood clotting in the lungs, heart, brain, and legs, and low platelet count.

Lupus Anticoagulant Test Explained

A laboratory diagnostic test called the lupus anticoagulant test is used to find out if autoantibodies known as lupus anticoagulant, which obstruct normal clotting are present. The examination focuses on LA, Because the presence of lupus anticoagulants may suggest a greater tendency for irregular blood clotting, this test is very important in determining the risk of thrombotic events. To find out whether there are lupus anticoagulants in the blood, a lupus anticoagulant test entails multiple laboratory evaluations. 

  • Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT): The amount of time it takes for a blood sample to clot after a reagent is introduced is known as the Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time or aPTT. This measurement is used to determine the intrinsic pathway of blood clotting. An extended aPTT may be a sign of lupus anticoagulant interference. 
  • Russell Viper Venom Test (RVVT): Using venom that triggers the clotting cascade, the Russell Viper Venom Test (RVVT) precisely looks for lupus anticoagulants; if the clotting time is delayed, it indicates their existence.
  • Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test (dRVVT): increases the detection of these antibodies by using a diluted venom concentration.
  • Lupus Anticoagulant Screen: The Lupus Anticoagulant Screen looks for antibodies that lead to irregular blood clotting. The exam consists of a set of evaluations that could include: uses reagents containing phospholipids to measure the time required for a plasma sample to clot. In the mixing study, the patient’s plasma is mixed equally with normal plasma, and the clotting time is then measured once more. In the Confirmatory test: Add more phospholipid to correct the extended clotting time.

Symptoms of Lupus Anticoagulant

Lupus anticoagulants can heighten the risk of abnormal blood clotting, which may lead to a range of symptoms and health issues. The symptoms associated with lupus anticoagulant primarily arise from the formation of blood clots and can include the following:

  • Recurrent Miscarriages: A higher chance of recurrent miscarriages, frequently in the first trimester, is linked to the presence of lupus anticoagulants.
  • Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): When a blood clot forms in a deep vein, generally in the legs, Visible surface veins and swelling, soreness, or pain in the affected leg—which may feel warm to the touch are possible symptoms.
  • Stroke: A stroke may result from a clot preventing blood flow to the brain. A person may have sudden numbness or weakness in one or both eyes, loss of balance or coordination, disorientation, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and weakness in the face, arm, or leg (particularly on one side). 
  • Pulmonary Embolism (PE): Pulmonary embolism may result from a clot that escapes from a deep vein thrombosis and travels to the lungs. Anxiety, rapid heartbeat, coughing up blood, severe chest pain that seems like a heart attack, and shortness of breath all occur suddenly.

Treatment

When it comes to managing lupus anticoagulants, an effective treatment plan is crucial to reduce the risk of complications from abnormal blood clotting. Treatment options typically aim to prevent clot formation, alleviate symptoms, and enhance the overall quality of life for those affected.

  • Medications:Anticoagulants, or blood thinners, like warfarin, aspirin, and heparin, are an essential component of treatment. One major issue for people with lupus anticoagulants is the prevention of hazardous blood clots, which is something that these drugs help with.
  • Steroids: These may decrease the amount of LA antibodies that the immune system produces. Two examples of steroids are prednisone and cortisone.
  • Plasma Exchange: Plasma exchange, also known as plasmapheresis, During this process, blood plasma—which includes harmful antibodies—is extracted and replaced with healthy plasma. By decreasing the levels of autoantibodies of lupus anticoagulants, plasma exchange can enhance the patient’s general health and lower the chance of clotting.
  • Lifestyle Changes: A healthy lifestyle that includes consistent exercise, eating a balanced diet, staying at a healthy weight, and quitting smoking is suggested for patients. Another important factor in lowering the risk of blood clots is maintaining adequate hydration and avoiding prolonged periods of immobility.

Together, these treatments aim to manage the symptoms of lupus anticoagulant while minimizing the risk of complications, particularly clotting. Regular follow-up with healthcare providers is crucial for effective management.

In conclusion, the lupus anticoagulant test is essential for identifying the presence of lupus anticoagulants, which can increase the risk of blood clots. By detecting these autoantibodies, doctors can better understand a patient’s risk and create effective treatment plans. These plans often include anticoagulant medications to prevent clots, along with lifestyle changes that support overall health. 

Treatments like steroids and plasma exchange can also help reduce harmful antibodies. Regular check-ups are important for managing symptoms and adjusting treatments. With the right care and knowledge, individuals with lupus anticoagulant can better manage their health and reduce the risk of complications.
